significant hydronephrosis, but there is periureteral stranding of the left

mucosal thickening at the ureterovesicular junction. Findings may represent a
recently passed stone with evidence of forniceal rupture, however, given the

malignancy is not excluded.  Correlate with current urinalysis, and recommend
followup urinalysis with cytology and possibly ultrasound (if the latter

LUMBAR SPINE MRI WITHOUT CONTRAST, ___

INDICATION:  Lower back pain radiating to the left leg.

COMPARISON:  No previous dedicated lumbar spine imaging.

TECHNIQUE:  Sagittal T1- and T2-weighted images of the lumbar spine, with
axial T2-weighted images from T12-L1 through L5-S1 interspaces.

FINDINGS:  Bone marrow signal is diffusely heterogeneous, but predominantly
abnormally low on T1-weighted images.  An exception is the vertebral body of
L3, which demonstrates mostly high signal on T1- and T2-weighted images,
suggesting complete fatty replacement.  Vertebral body height is preserved. 
Alignment is within normal limits.  The distal spinal cord appears
unremarkable in morphology and signal intensity, with the conus medullaris
terminating at L1-2.  No intrathecal abnormalities are detected on
non-contrast evaluation.

At T12-L1, there is a minimal disc bulge without spinal canal or neural
foraminal narrowing.

At L1-2, there is a minimal disc bulge without spinal canal or neural
foraminal narrowing.

At L2-3, there is a disc bulge and a left lateral disc protrusion, with left
paracentral and foraminal components.  The protrusion contacts the traversing
left L3 nerve root, displacing it posteriorly.  There is no significant neural
foraminal narrowing or impingement of the exiting L2 nerve roots.

At L3-4, there is a mild disc bulge and right greater than left facet
arthropathy.  There is no significant spinal canal or neural foraminal
narrowing.

At L4-5, there is a disc bulge with bilateral facet arthropathy, but no
significant spinal canal narrowing.  There is also a right foraminal disc
protrusion with overlying endplate osteophytes, resulting in mild-to-moderate
right neural foraminal narrowing.

At L5-S1, there is a mild disc bulge without spinal canal narrowing.  There is
mild-to-moderate bilateral neural foraminal narrowing.

No signal abnormalities are detected in the imaged retroperitoneal soft
tissues.

IMPRESSION:
1.  Multilevel degenerative disease, as detailed above.  At L2-3, a left-sided
disc protrusion contacts the traversing left L3 nerve root in the subarticular
recess, displacing it posteriorly.  Mild to moderate narrowing of the right
L4-5 and bilateral L5-S1 neural foramina.
2.  Diffusely abnormal bone marrow signal, which may be seen in red marrow
reconversion in the setting of anemia, smoking, or chronic systemic illness,
or else secondary to an infiltrative disorder.  Please correlate with clinical
history and laboratory data.
3.  Apparent fatty replacement of the L3 vertebral body, which may be seen
following radiation therapy or other insults.  Please correlate clinically.

PROCEDURE:  CT interventional procedure, CT-guided percutaneous biopsy of
right lower lobe lung nodule, RFA aborted.

radiofrequency ablation.  Patient has history of right upper lobe wedge
resection with benign findings.

PROCEDURE:  The risks and benefits of the procedure were explained to the
patient, and written informed consent was obtained.  A preprocedure timeout
was performed verifying three patient identifiers and the nature of the
procedure to be performed.  Patient was placed prone on the CT table, and
placed under general anesthesia for the entire duration of the procedure. 
Initial non-contrast CT images were obtained through the lower chest, which
demonstrated the presence of an 11 mm nodule in the right lower lobe
costophrenic angle.  In addition, a new 6 mm nodule is noted to be adjacent to
the mass, not seen on prior PET-CT.The skin overlying the right back was
prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion.  Under direct CT fluoroscopic
guidance, a 20-gauge biopsy needle system was advanced to the two adjacent
right lower lobe nodules, and a single core biopsy specimen was obtained and
sent for cytology and pathology analysis.  Initial cytology found the tissue
to be highly suspicious for carcinoma.  Post-procedure limited CT immediately
post biopsy demonstrated a small amount of perilesional hemorrhage, which
significantly obscured the lesion in the right lower lobe.  There was no
evidence of pneumothorax.  The needle guide was removed, and a 10 minute
delayed chest CT was obtained.  10 minute delayed limited CT of the lower
chest demonstrated persistence of the stable perilesional hemorrhage, which
obscured the lesion, rendering it impossible to proceed with the
radiofrequency ablation.  There was no evidence of pneumothorax on the 10
minute delayed scan.  Plan is to bring the patient back in four weeks after
the bleeding has cleared for radiofrequency ablation.  Dry sterile dressing
was placed.  The patient tolerated the procedure well, with no complications
evident at the time of the procedure.  The attending radiologist, Dr.
___, was present and supervising throughout the procedure.

PRE-PROCEDURE IMAGING FINDINGS:  Left basilar subsegmental atelectasis.  Mild
right basilar subsegmental atelectasis.  In the superior segment of the right
lower lobe is noted an 8 mm nodule, unchanged since prior PET-CT.  In the
right lower lobe costophrenic angle is again seen an 11 mm nodule, similar in
size to prior PET-CT.  However, there is a new 6 mm nodule anterior to the 11
mm nodule, this 6 mm nodule appears new and most likely represents interval
growth of malignancy.  Significant coronary atherosclerosis again noted. 
Moderate calcific atherosclerosis of the aorta.  Elevation of the right
hemidiaphragm again seen.

POST-PROCEDURE IMAGING FINDINGS:  Again visualized is bibasilar subsegmental
atelectasis.  Small amount of perilesional hemorrhage is seen in the right
lower lobe, obscuring the two small nodules.  Again visualized is coronary
atherosclerosis and aortic calcific atherosclerosis.  Again noted is the 8 mm
superior segment right lower lobe nodule, unchanged since prior PET-CT.

IMPRESSION:

Technically successful CT-guided percutaneous biopsy of right lower lobe
nodules, with new satellite nodule since prior PET-CT.  Post-procedure limited
CT demonstrated small amount of perilesional hemorrhage, which obscured the
right lower lobe lesion, not possible to proceed with radiofrequency ablation
today. Patient will be brought back in four weeks after bleeding has cleared
